3 Ways to Reset Your BIOS - wikiHow 
 Home Random Browse Articles Notifications Add to This Page Add Tip Easy Ways to Help Approve Questions Review Tech Feedback Fix Spelling More Things to Try...   
 Log in / Sign up   
 Desktop Site   
 Talk How to Reset Your BIOS   
 This wikiHow teaches you how to reset your Windows computer's BIOS (short for Basic Input/Output Settings) to factory settings.You can do this on most computers from the BIOS page; however, if you're locked out of your computer's BIOS, you'll need to reset the BIOS by opening your computer's housing and removing the CMOS battery from the motherboard, or--in the case of desktops--resetting the jumper switch on the motherboard. 
 In some cases, opening your computer's housing will void your warranty, and you run a significant risk of permanently damaging your computer while doing so.  If you can't access your BIOS, your best course of action is to take the computer into a tech department instead of doing it yourself. 
 10 Second Summary Edit 
 1. Restart your computer. 
2. Press your computer's  BIOS key . 
3. Select the  "Setup Defaults" option . 
4. Press  ↵  Enter . 
 Steps Edit 
 Method One of Three: Resetting from Within BIOS Edit 
 1 
 Restart your computer.  Open Start
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/07\/Windowsstart.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760} 
, click the power icon
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/5d\/Windowspower.png","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/5d\/Windowspower.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760} 
, and click  Restart .
 If your computer is locked, click the lock screen, then click the power icon in the bottom-right corner of the screen and click  Restart . 
 If your computer is already off, press your computer's "On" switch. 
 2 
 Wait for the computer's first startup screen to appear.  Once the startup screen appears, you'll have a very limited window in which you can press the setup key.
 It's best to start pressing the setup key as soon as the computer begins to restart. 
 If you see "Press [key] to enter setup" or something similar flash across the bottom of the screen and then disappear, you'll need to restart and try again. 
 3 
 Repeatedly tap  Del  or  F2  to enter setup.  The key you're prompted to press might also be different; if so, use that key instead.
 If  Del  or  F2  don't work, try  F8   F10   Esc  or  Tab  ↹ . 
 You'll typically use the "F" keys to access the BIOS. These are at the top of your keyboard, though you may have to locate and hold the  Fn  key while pressing the proper "F" key. 
 You can look at your computer model's manual or online support page to confirm your computer's BIOS key. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e4\/Change-Computer-BIOS-Settings-Step-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Change-Computer-BIOS-Settings-Step-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e4\/Change-Computer-BIOS-Settings-Step-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Change-Computer-BIOS-Settings-Step-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 4 
 Wait for your BIOS to load.  After successfully hitting the setup key, the BIOS will load. This should only take a few moments. When the loading is complete, you will be taken to the BIOS settings menu.
 If you cannot access your BIOS because you are locked out with a password or it has been corrupted, use one of the other methods in this article. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/bb\/40069-2.jpg\/v4-460px-40069-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/bb\/40069-2.jpg\/v4-760px-40069-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 5 
 Find the "Setup Defaults" option.  The location and wording of this option varies for every different BIOS, but it will typically be called "Reset to Default", "Factory Default", "Setup Defaults", or something similar. It may be located in one of the tabs or it may be an option listed near the navigation buttons.
 If your BIOS does not have this option, use one of the following methods following this section. 
 6 
 Select the "Load Setup Defaults" option and press  ↵  Enter .  Use the arrow keys to select it; pressing  ↵  Enter  will usually begin resetting your BIOS immediately.
 Again, the wording of the option you select will likely differ for each BIOS. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/38\/40069-3.jpg\/v4-460px-40069-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/38\/40069-3.jpg\/v4-760px-40069-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 7 
 Save your changes and confirm your selection if necessary.  This will often be combined with the process of exiting a BIOS. Your computer will automatically reboot. If you need to change your BIOS settings once your BIOS resets, you may need to reboot your computer again and enter the BIOS to change them.
 Advertisement 
 Method Two of Three: Removing the CMOS Battery Edit 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e1\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-2.jpg\/v4-459px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e1\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-2.jpg\/v4-759px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306.45604395604,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868} 
 1 
 Power down your computer.  Either use the Start menu to shut down, or press and hold your computer's power button until the computer shuts down.
 If you're using a desktop computer, you can usually turn the CPU entirely off by pressing a switch on the back of the CPU box. 
 2 
 Unplug your computer from any power sources.  This includes power cables for desktop computers and charging cables for laptops. 
 3 
 Remove your computer's battery if necessary.  If you're using a laptop (or a desktop with a backup battery), remove the battery before continuing. 
 4 
 Discharge any static electricity  before continuing.  Touch a nonpainted metal surface to get rid of any static electricity before you start taking apart your computer. Touching the motherboard or other internal computer components while not properly grounded can permanently damage your computer. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1d\/40069-13.jpg\/v4-460px-40069-13.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1d\/40069-13.jpg\/v4-760px-40069-13.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 5 
 Open your case.  You will need to be able to access the motherboard of your computer. Be very careful when working on the inside of your computer, as electrostatic discharge can easily destroy sensitive components.
 For many laptops, you can access the CMOS battery from a removable panel on the bottom of the laptop. If there is no panel available, you will most likely need to disassemble the laptop to access it. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c0\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-18.jpg\/v4-459px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-18.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c0\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-18.jpg\/v4-759px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-18.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306.45604395604,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868} 
 6 
 Remove the CMOS battery.  The battery is typically located near your PCI slots, but may be in different locations depending on the manufacturer of your motherboard. It may be hidden by expansion cards and cables. The battery is usually a standard 3V, round, flat watch battery (CR2032).
 The CMOS battery isn't always removable. If the battery won't budge, don't force it; instead, try  resetting your motherboard's jumper . 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e9\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-21.jpg\/v4-459px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-21.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e9\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-21.jpg\/v4-759px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-21.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306.45604395604,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868} 
 7 
 Press your power button.  Press and hold the power button on your computer for about 10-15 seconds to discharge any remaining power stored in the capacitors. By discharging the power, the CMOS memory will reset, thereby resetting your BIOS.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/53\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-19.jpg\/v4-459px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-19.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/53\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-19.jpg\/v4-759px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-19.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306.45604395604,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868} 
 8 
 Reinsert the CMOS battery.  Carefully reinsert the CMOS battery back into its housing. Make sure that you have put the battery in the right direction. The slightly smaller side should be facing down.
 9 
 Reassemble your computer.  Do so carefully, and remember to ground yourself periodically. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/5f\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-20.jpg\/v4-459px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-20.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/5f\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-20.jpg\/v4-759px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-20.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306.45604395604,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868} 
 10 
 Reconnect your computer's power source(s).  If you unplugged the computer from the wall and/or removed the battery, plug it back in and/or replace the battery.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/33\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-10.jpg\/v4-459px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-10.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/33\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-10.jpg\/v4-759px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-10.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306.45604395604,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868} 
 11 
 Turn back on your computer.  Depending on your computer, you may have to access the BIOS and reconfigure some of the options, including the default boot option or the date and time.
 Advertisement 
 Method Three of Three: Resetting the Jumper Edit 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e1\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-2.jpg\/v4-459px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/e1\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-2.jpg\/v4-759px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306.45604395604,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868} 
 1 
 Power down your computer.  Either use the Start menu to shut down, or press and hold your computer's power button until the computer shuts down.
 If you're using a desktop computer, you can usually turn the CPU entirely off by pressing a switch on the back of the CPU box. 
 2 
 Unplug your computer from any power sources.  This includes power cables for desktop computers and charging cables for laptops. 
 3 
 Remove your computer's battery if necessary.  If you're using a laptop (or a desktop with a backup battery), remove the battery before continuing. 
 4 
 Discharge any static electricity  before continuing.  Touch a nonpainted metal surface to get rid of any static electricity before you start taking apart your computer. Touching the motherboard or other internal computer components while not properly grounded can permanently damage your computer. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1d\/40069-13.jpg\/v4-460px-40069-13.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1d\/40069-13.jpg\/v4-760px-40069-13.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 5 
 Open your case.  You will need to be able to access the motherboard of your computer. Be very careful when working on the inside of your computer, as electrostatic discharge can easily destroy sensitive components.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/fa\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/fa\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":316.56593406593,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":523.02197802198} 
 6 
 Find the CMOS jumper.  Locate the three-pin jumper on your motherboard that controls the BIOS. It will usually found near the CMOS battery. The jumper will be covering two of the three pins.
 The jumper may be labeled CLEAR, CLR, CLEAR CMOS, PSSWRD, or a variety of other labels. Refer to your motherboard's documentation to find the correct jumper. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2e\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-5.jpg\/v4-459px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-5.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2e\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-5.jpg\/v4-759px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-5.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306.45604395604,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868} 
 7 
 Move the jumper to the other two pins.  For example, if the jumper is covering the first and second pins, move it so that it is covering the second and third pins. Be sure to pull the jumper straight up to remove it so that you don't bend the pins.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/dc\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-6.jpg\/v4-459px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-6.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/dc\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-6.jpg\/v4-759px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-6.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306.45604395604,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868} 
 8 
 Press your power button.  Press and hold the power button on your computer for about 10-15 seconds to discharge any remaining power stored in the capacitors. This will make the BIOS reset.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/71\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-8.jpg\/v4-459px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-8.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/71\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-8.jpg\/v4-759px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-8.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306.45604395604,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868} 
 9 
 Return the jumper to its default position.  Put the jumper back on the pins that it was originally on. This will allow you to access your BIOS when you start your computer up.
 10 
 Reassemble your computer.  Do so carefully, and remember to ground yourself periodically. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/5f\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-20.jpg\/v4-459px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-20.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/5f\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-20.jpg\/v4-759px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-20.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306.45604395604,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868} 
 11 
 Reconnect your computer's power source(s).  If you unplugged the computer from the wall and/or removed the battery, plug it back in and/or replace the battery.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/33\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-10.jpg\/v4-459px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-10.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/33\/Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-10.jpg\/v4-759px-Reset-Your-BIOS-Step-10.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306.45604395604,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868} 
 12 
 Turn back on your computer.  Depending on your computer, you may have to access the BIOS and reconfigure some of the options, including the default boot option or the date and time.
 Advertisement 
 Community Q&A 
 Search 
 Add New Question 
 Can switching internet providers cause my firmware to update and mess up my computer? 
								Answered by  
								wikiHow Contributor							 
 No it can't. You issue was likely caused by something else which coincidentally occurred around the time you switched Internet providers. 
 Thanks! 
 17 
 2 
 How do I reset my BIOS after a failed BIOS flashing or overclocking attempt? 
								Answered by  
								wikiHow Contributor							 
 If you tried to flash your BIOS with incorrect firmware, you may be able to reset it using a BIOS Recovery jumper. This jumper's location varies for every motherboard, so refer to your motherboard's documentation to find it. Removing this jumper may allow you to load a BIOS recovery file. 
 Thanks! 
 22 
 10 
 I am trying to reset my BIOS but I have lost the jumper. How can I reset it without it? 
								Answered by  
								wikiHow Contributor							 
 Instead of removing the jumper, remove the battery. The procedure is the same.  
 Thanks! 
 5 
 1 
 What should I do if my PC won't start after updating Windows? 
								Answered by  
								wikiHow Contributor							 
 If you've recently updated Windows and now your PC won't start, the problem is probably not with your BIOS. Resetting your BIOS may help, but you'll likely need to reinstall Windows or perform a Windows repair in order to get it working again. 
 Thanks! 
 16 
 11 
 I have one DDR2 1 GB RAM and 2 GB RAM. Can I use both at the same time when my system is not running? 
								Answered by  
								wikiHow Contributor							 
 Yes, you can as long as they are both DDR2 and the speeds are the same. Also, check with your motherboard's manufacturer to see what your maximum amount of RAM is. 
 Thanks! 
 2 
 0 
 I've done the CMOS battery method, but it did not work. What else can I try? 
								Answered by  
								wikiHow Contributor							 
 You can try replacing your motherboard, especially if it keeps displaying Checksum Error or CMOS battery low message. 
 Thanks! 
 6 
 4 
 How do I reset my BIOS password? 
								Answered by  
								wikiHow Contributor							 
 If you're locked out of your computer because of a BIOS password, you may be able to reset it by using the password jumper on the motherboard. If you don't have access to the motherboard, such as on a laptop, you'll need to find a backdoor password to bypass the lock. 
 Thanks! 
 12 
 18 
 What do I do if Samsung's BIOS Boot Priority menu is empty? 
								Answered by  
								wikiHow Contributor							 
 This is likely caused by settings in your BIOS. Open your BIOS menu and disable Fast BIOS and Secure Boot. This should allow you to select different devices in the Boot Priority menu. 
 Thanks! 
 5 
 7 
 What do I do if my computer has no display after I add RAM? 
								Answered by  
								wikiHow Contributor							 
 The RAM is most likely incompatible with your machine.  Check your computer's manual or support site online to determine allowable size/speed of RAM upgrades.     
 Thanks! 
 0 
 0 
 I have an Alienware 17 R4, and recently updated the BIOS. Now I have a black screen, a half-lit keyboard, and my computer boot loops with 7 beeps. What should I do? 
								Answered by  
								wikiHow Contributor							 
 You can find a full list of beep codes on the Dell support page. 7 beeps indicates a CPU cache error, and is not user-serviceable. Contact Dell technical support to get it fixed. 
 Thanks!

 Tips Edit 
 Without any custom configuration, most systems should still function adequately with their default BIOS settings.

 Warnings Edit 
 Ground yourself before handling any components inside a PC to reduce the risk of electrostatic discharge from damaging your PC.
